user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of test_header:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
test_header (void *cls,
             const char *key,
             size_t key_size,
             const char *value,
             size_t value_size,
             enum MHD_ValueKind kind)
{
  struct test_header_param *const param = (struct test_header_param *) cls;
  struct MHD_Connection *connection = param->connection;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;
  size_t i;

  param->num_headers++;
  i = 0;
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (kind != pos->kind)
      continue;
    if (++i == param->num_headers)
    {
      if (key_size != pos->header_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      if (value_size != pos->value_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      if (0 != key_size)
      {
        mhd_assert (NULL != key);
        mhd_assert (NULL != pos->header);
        if (0 != memcmp (key,
                         pos->header,
                         key_size))
          return MHD_NO;
      }
      if (0 != value_size)
      {
        mhd_assert (NULL != value);
        mhd_assert (NULL != pos->value);
        if (0 != memcmp (value,
                         pos->value,
                         value_size))
          return MHD_NO;
      }
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameters are modified in this function. Analysis by parameter:
- cls: Only cast to struct test_header_param* and used to access param->connection and param->num_headers. The statement param->num_headers++ modifies the object pointed to by cls, which is permitted by the rule (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified). The pointer parameter cls itself is not assigned to or altered.
- key and value (const char*): Used only in mhd_assert checks and passed to memcmp; neither the pointers nor the characters they point to are modified. They are treated as const throughout.
- key_size and value_size (size_t): Only read and compared against pos->header_size and pos->value_size; not assigned to or modified.
- kind (enum MHD_ValueKind): Only read and compared to pos->kind; not modified.
Other local variables (param, connection, pos, i) are locals and may be modified. No pointer parameter is reassigned, so there are no violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in this code fragment.
